title: 115_s1268
content: The Act titled "Child Protection and Family Support Act of 2017" allows foster care maintenance payments for children with parents in licensed residential family-based treatment facilities for substance abuse. The Child Protection and Family Support Act of 2017 amends Section 472 of the Social Security Act to allow foster care maintenance payments for children with parents in licensed residential family-based treatment facilities for substance abuse. Eligibility for these payments is extended to children in such situations. Children placed with a parent in a licensed residential family-based treatment facility for substance abuse may be eligible for foster care maintenance payments for up to 12 months. The placement must be recommended in the child's case plan, and the facility must offer parenting skills training, education, and counseling as part of the substance abuse treatment program. The text chunk discusses the application of trauma-informed approaches and interventions for children in foster care. It also includes a conforming amendment to the Social Security Act. Enhancements to grants for families affected by substance abuse. Section 437(f) of the Social Security Act is amended to implement IV-E Prevention Services and improve the well-being and permanency outcomes for children and families affected by methamphetamine, heroin, opioids, and other substances. It defines a regional partnership as a collaborative agreement involving mandatory partners for all partnership grants. The State child welfare agency and the State agency responsible for administering substance abuse prevention grants are mandatory partners for partnership grants. If serving children in out-of-home placements, the Juvenile Court or Administrative Office of the Court must oversee the administration. The partnership overseeing court programs for families involved in child abuse or neglect may include optional partners such as Indian tribes, nonprofit and for-profit child welfare providers, community health and mental health providers, local law enforcement, and school personnel. The partnership for court programs involving child abuse or neglect may include Indian tribes, child welfare providers, health providers, law enforcement, and school personnel. Indian tribes or tribal consortia in regional partnerships are not required to include the State child welfare agency as a partner. The collaborative agreement for court programs involving child abuse or neglect may include tribal child welfare agencies, tribal court organizations, and other partners.
